elements.content: Four bimetallic assemblies involving chiral metal complexes and tetracyanonickelate, {[M(L) m ][Ni(CN)4]·nH2O}∞ (M = NiII, m = 3, n = 4 (1), M = CuII, m = 2, n = 2 (2 and 4), M = CuII, m = 2, n = 0 (3), and where L = R,R-chxn = trans-cyclohexane-(1R,2R)-diamine for 1, 2 and 3; and S,S-chxn = trans-cyclohexane-(1S,2S)-diamine for 4), have been synthesized and structurally characterized. The crystal structure analysis of compound 1 reveals that it consists of discrete [Ni(R,R-chxn)3]2+ cations and [Ni(CN)4]2− anions. Compound 2 is a bimetallic assembly of a [Cu(R,R-chxn)3]2+ cation and a [Ni(CN)4]2− anion. For compound 2 an interesting reversible phase transformation was observed. This bimetallic complex can be transformed into a one-dimensional polymer structure, 3, accompanied by a color change from violet to purple, simply by the removal of the water molecules of crystallization on heating. Rehydration of 3 gives 2, confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction. Compound 4 is also a one-dimensional zigzag polymer composed of alternating trans-[Cu(S,S-chxn)2]2+ cations and [Ni(CN)4]2− anions. Circular dichroism (CD) measurements for 2 and 4, and immersion calorimetric studies on compound 3 have been carried out.
elements.clean_text: Four bimetallic assemblies involving chiral metal complexes and tetracyanonickelate, {[M(L) m ][Ni(CN)4]⋅nH2O}∞ (M = NiII, m = 3, n = 4 (1), M = CuII, m = 2, n = 2 (2 and 4), M = CuII, m = 2, n = 0 (3), and where L = R,R-chxn = trans-cyclohexane-(1R,2R)-diamine for 1, 2 and 3; and S,S-chxn = trans-cyclohexane-(1S,2S)-diamine for 4), have been synthesized and structurally characterized. The crystal structure analysis of compound 1 reveals that it consists of discrete [Ni(R,R-chxn)3]2+ cations and [Ni(CN)4]2- anions. Compound 2 is a bimetallic assembly of a [Cu(R,R-chxn)3]2+ cation and a [Ni(CN)4]2- anion. For compound 2 an interesting reversible phase transformation was observed. This bimetallic complex can be transformed into a one-dimensional polymer structure, 3, accompanied by a color change from violet to purple, simply by the removal of the water molecules of crystallization on heating. Rehydration of 3 gives 2, confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction. Compound 4 is also a one-dimensional zigzag polymer composed of alternating trans-[Cu(S,S-chxn)2]2+ cations and [Ni(CN)4]2- anions. Circular dichroism (CD) measurements for 2 and 4, and immersion calorimetric studies on compound 3 have been carried out.

elements.content: Four new bimetallic chiral tetracyanonickelate(II) complexes, two of which are one-dimensional polymers, have been synthesized and fully characterized. The phase transformation of a binuclear structure into a one-dimensional chiral polymer was analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction and immersion calorimetric studies.
elements.clean_text: Four new bimetallic chiral tetracyanonickelate(II) complexes, two of which are one-dimensional polymers, have been synthesized and fully characterized. The phase transformation of a binuclear structure into a one-dimensional chiral polymer was analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction and immersion calorimetric studies.

elements.content: Chirality is of fundamental importance for life and plays a key role in biological systems and pharmacy. At the same time, chirality is a key factor for exhibiting specific physical properties, such as second harmonic generation (SHG), magneto-chiral dichroism (MChD), ferroelectricity, etc. On the other hand, the study of cyanide-bridged metal complexes is an old but ever green branch in the field of coordination chemistry. Cyanide-bridged bimetallic complexes deserve special attention as they exhibit interesting electrochemical, zeolitic, magnetic, and photomagnetic properties. However, most of the cyanide-bridged bimetallic complexes obtained so far involve achiral components, and consequently, only a limited number of chiral structures have been studied. Here we report on the characterization, including the structural and physical properties, of four new bimetallic chiral tetracyanonickelate(II) complexes: [Ni(R,R-chxn)3][Ni(CN)4]·4H2O (1) and [Cu(R,R-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]·2H2O (2), {[Cu(R,R-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]}∞ (3) and {[Cu(S,S-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]·2H2O}∞ (4) (where R,R-chxn = trans-cyclohexane-(1R, 2R)-diamine and S,S-chxn = trans-cyclohexane-(1S, 2S)-diamine).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Chirality is of fundamental importance for life and plays a key role in biological systems and pharmacy. At the same time, chirality is a key factor for exhibiting specific physical properties, such as second harmonic generation (SHG), magneto-chiral dichroism (MChD), ferroelectricity, etc. On the other hand, the study of cyanide-bridged metal complexes is an old but ever green branch in the field of coordination chemistry. Cyanide-bridged bimetallic complexes deserve special attention as they exhibit interesting electrochemical, zeolitic, magnetic, and photomagnetic properties. However, most of the cyanide-bridged bimetallic complexes obtained so far involve achiral components, and consequently, only a limited number of chiral structures have been studied. Here we report on the characterization, including the structural and physical properties, of four new bimetallic chiral tetracyanonickelate(II) complexes: [Ni(R,R-chxn)3][Ni(CN)4]⋅4H2O (1) and [Cu(R,R-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]⋅2H2O (2), {[Cu(R,R-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]}∞ (3) and {[Cu(S,S-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]⋅2H2O}∞ (4) (where R,R-chxn = trans-cyclohexane-(1R, 2R)-diamine and S,S-chxn = trans-cyclohexane-(1S, 2S)-diamine).

elements.content: Compound 1 was obtained as pink rod-like crystals by slow diffusion of an aqueous solution of [Ni(R,R-chxn)3]SO4 layered onto a H2O-EtOH (1:1) solution of K2[Ni(CN)4] after several weeks. Elemental analysis for C22H46N10Ni2O4: calc. C, 41.81; H, 7.34; N, 22.16, found C, 41.54; H, 7.92; N, 22.02%.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses

[Ni(R,R-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]⋅4H2O (1)

Compound 1 was obtained as pink rod-like crystals by slow diffusion of an aqueous solution of [Ni(R,R-chxn)3]SO4 layered onto a H2O-EtOH (1:1) solution of K2[Ni(CN)4] after several weeks. Elemental analysis for C22H46N10Ni2O4: calc. C, 41.81; H, 7.34; N, 22.16, found C, 41.54; H, 7.92; N, 22.02%.

elements.content: Compound 2 was obtained as violet plate-like crystals by layering an aqueous solution of [Cu(R,R-chxn)3]SO4 layered onto a H2O-EtOH(1:1) solution of K2[Ni(CN)4] after several weeks. The crystals have a slightly smaller unit cell than the same structure published by Akitsu et al., due to the fact the crystal was measured at −100 °C. Elemental analysis for C16H32N8CuNiO2: calc. C, 39.16; H, 6.57; N, 22.83, found C, 39.26; H, 6.48; N, 22.99%.
elements.clean_text:
[Cu(R,R-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]⋅2H2O (2)

Compound 2 was obtained as violet plate-like crystals by layering an aqueous solution of [Cu(R,R-chxn)3]SO4 layered onto a H2O-EtOH(1:1) solution of K2[Ni(CN)4] after several weeks. The crystals have a slightly smaller unit cell than the same structure published by Akitsu et al., due to the fact the crystal was measured at -100 °C. Elemental analysis for C16H32N8CuNiO2: calc. C, 39.16; H, 6.57; N, 22.83, found C, 39.26; H, 6.48; N, 22.99%.

elements.content: Complex 3 was obtained as a purple powder by heating compound 2 to 110 °C, using thermogravimetric analysis. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C16H28N8CuNi: C, 42.27; H, 6.21; N, 24.64, found C, 42.26; H, 6.36; N, 24.26%.
elements.clean_text:
{[Cu(R,R-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]}∞ (3)

Complex 3 was obtained as a purple powder by heating compound 2 to 110 °C, using thermogravimetric analysis. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C16H28N8CuNi: C, 42.27; H, 6.21; N, 24.64, found C, 42.26; H, 6.36; N, 24.26%.

elements.content: Compound 4 was obtained as violet block-like crystals by slow diffusion of an acetonitrile solution of [Cu(trans-(S,S-chxn)2(H2O)](NO3)2 (1mmol, 10 mL) layered onto an aqueous solution of K2[Ni(CN)4]·H2O (1mmol, 10 mL). Elemental analysis for C16H32N8CuNiO2: calc. C, 39.16; H, 6.57; N, 22.83, found C, 39.32; H, 6.71; N, 22.93%.
elements.clean_text:
{[Cu(S,S-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]⋅2H2O}∞ (4)

Compound 4 was obtained as violet block-like crystals by slow diffusion of an acetonitrile solution of [Cu(trans-(S,S-chxn)2(H2O)](NO3)2 (1mmol, 10 mL) layered onto an aqueous solution of K2[Ni(CN)4]⋅H2O (1mmol, 10 mL). Elemental analysis for C16H32N8CuNiO2: calc. C, 39.16; H, 6.57; N, 22.83, found C, 39.32; H, 6.71; N, 22.93%.

elements.content: The intensity data for crystals of compounds 1, 2, and 4 were collected at 173 K (−100 °C) on Stoe Image Plate Diffraction Systems, equipped either with a one-circle or a two-circle goniometer, using Mo Kα graphite monochromated radiation (λ = 0.71083 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods using the program SHELXS-97. The refinement and all further calculations were carried out using SHELXL-97. The water and NH2 H-atoms were located from Fourier difference maps and freely refined. The remainder of the H-atoms were included in calculated positions and treated as riding atoms using SHELXL default parameters. The non-H atoms were refined anisotropically, using weighted full-matrix least-squares on F2. The structure of complex 3 was solved and refined by X-ray powder methods (). The microcrystalline powder was inserted in a glass capillary of a 0.5 mm diameter. X-ray powder data were collected at room temperature on a computer controlled STOE-STADIP focusing powder diffractometer equipped with a curved Ge(111) monochromator (Cu Kα1, λ = 1.54051 Å). A STOE linear position sensitive detector (PSD) was used. The data were collected in the range of 4° ≤ 2θ ≤ 90° using a step width of 0.1°. The indexing procedure was performed using ITO in WinXPow. The structure solution was carried out using the program DASH introducing a structural model. The obtained position of the molecule in the given symmetry and unit cell was used for Rietveld refinement in GSAS/EXPGUI.One small impurity peak at 2θ = 8.2° has been excluded from the refinement. After the initial refinement of the scale and unit cell constants, the atomic positions were refined using soft constraints defining the geometry of the molecule within some allowable errors. Subsequent Rietveld refinement was carried out gradually relaxing the bond restraints. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined isotropically applying an overall temperature factor for the all C and N atoms. The H-atoms were treated as riding atoms, with fixed temperature factors. In the final cycles of refinement, the shifts for all of the parameters were less than their standard uncertainties. Further crystallographic and refinement details for compounds 1−4 are given in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Analyses

The intensity data for crystals of compounds 1, 2, and 4 were collected at 173 K (-100 °C) on Stoe Image Plate Diffraction Systems, equipped either with a one-circle or a two-circle goniometer, using Mo Kα graphite monochromated radiation (λ = 0.71083 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods using the program SHELXS-97. The refinement and all further calculations were carried out using SHELXL-97. The water and NH2 H-atoms were located from Fourier difference maps and freely refined. The remainder of the H-atoms were included in calculated positions and treated as riding atoms using SHELXL default parameters. The non-H atoms were refined anisotropically, using weighted full-matrix least-squares on F2. The structure of complex 3 was solved and refined by X-ray powder methods (). The microcrystalline powder was inserted in a glass capillary of a 0.5 mm diameter. X-ray powder data were collected at room temperature on a computer controlled STOE-STADIP focusing powder diffractometer equipped with a curved Ge(111) monochromator (Cu Kα1, λ = 1.54051 Å). A STOE linear position sensitive detector (PSD) was used. The data were collected in the range of 4° ≤ 2θ ≤ 90° using a step width of 0.1°. The indexing procedure was performed using ITO in WinXPow. The structure solution was carried out using the program DASH introducing a structural model. The obtained position of the molecule in the given symmetry and unit cell was used for Rietveld refinement in GSAS/EXPGUI.One small impurity peak at 2θ = 8.2° has been excluded from the refinement. After the initial refinement of the scale and unit cell constants, the atomic positions were refined using soft constraints defining the geometry of the molecule within some allowable errors. Subsequent Rietveld refinement was carried out gradually relaxing the bond restraints. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined isotropically applying an overall temperature factor for the all C and N atoms. The H-atoms were treated as riding atoms, with fixed temperature factors. In the final cycles of refinement, the shifts for all of the parameters were less than their standard uncertainties. Further crystallographic and refinement details for compounds 1-4 are given in Table .

The crystal structure analysis of 1 revealed that it consists of discrete [Ni(R,R-chxn)3]2+ cations and [Ni(CN)4]2− anions and four molecules of water of crystallization (Figure ). The coordination geometry around the nickel atom of the cation, Ni1, has a slightly distorted octahedral geometry (average distance Ni1−N = 2.119(3) Å).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Ni(R,R-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]⋅4H2O (1)

The crystal structure analysis of 1 revealed that it consists of discrete [Ni(R,R-chxn)3]2+ cations and [Ni(CN)4]2- anions and four molecules of water of crystallization (Figure ). The coordination geometry around the nickel atom of the cation, Ni1, has a slightly distorted octahedral geometry (average distance Ni1-N = 2.119(3) Å).

elements.content: View of the asymmetric unit of 1 (H-atoms omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 1  View of the asymmetric unit of 1 (H-atoms omitted for clarity).

elements.content: As is usual, the [Ni(CN)4]2− anion exhibits a nearly planar structure (average bond lengths Ni2−C = 1.856(3) Å and C−N = 1.141(5) Å). The crystal packing of complex 1 viewed along the a-axis is shown in Figure . All four cyanide groups of the anion are engaged in hydrogen bonds with three water molecules and the NH2 groups of the ligand (d N7-O2 = 2.914(5) Å, d N7-N4 = 3.010(3) Å, d N8-O5 = 2.914(7) Å, d N8-N5 = 3.086(3) Å, d N9-O3 = 2.969(5) Å, d N9-O5 = 2.902(8) Å, d N10-O2 = 2.779(4) Å).
elements.clean_text: As is usual, the [Ni(CN)4]2- anion exhibits a nearly planar structure (average bond lengths Ni2-C = 1.856(3) Å and C-N = 1.141(5) Å). The crystal packing of complex 1 viewed along the a-axis is shown in Figure . All four cyanide groups of the anion are engaged in hydrogen bonds with three water molecules and the NH2 groups of the ligand (d N7-O2 = 2.914(5) Å, d N7-N4 = 3.010(3) Å, d N8-O5 = 2.914(7) Å, d N8-N5 = 3.086(3) Å, d N9-O3 = 2.969(5) Å, d N9-O5 = 2.902(8) Å, d N10-O2 = 2.779(4) Å).

elements.content: Crystal packing of complex 1 viewed along the a-axis. The water molecules are shown as red balls.
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal packing of complex 1 viewed along the a-axis. The water molecules are shown as red balls.

elements.content: Compound 2 was obtained as violet block-like crystals. The structure consists of a chiral [Cu(R,R-chxn)2]2+ cation linked to a [Ni(CN)4]2− anion, so forming a binuclear complex arranged in the crystal in a zigzag manner. The average bond lengths and angles, for example, the Cu1−N bond lengths involving the cyanide groups, are slightly shorter (by 0.03 Å) than those reported for the room temperature structure. On heating crystals of 2, the water molecules of crystallization are lost and a purple microcrystalline powder was obtained. Structure analysis of the high-resolution powder X-ray diffractogram () revealed that compound 2 had been transformed into a one-dimensional polymer {[Cu(R,Rchxn)2][Ni(CN)4]}∞ (3) (Figure a).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of [Cu(R,R-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]⋅2H2O (2) and {[Cu(R,R-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]}∞ (3)

Compound 2 was obtained as violet block-like crystals. The structure consists of a chiral [Cu(R,R-chxn)2]2+ cation linked to a [Ni(CN)4]2- anion, so forming a binuclear complex arranged in the crystal in a zigzag manner. The average bond lengths and angles, for example, the Cu1-N bond lengths involving the cyanide groups, are slightly shorter (by 0.03 Å) than those reported for the room temperature structure. On heating crystals of 2, the water molecules of crystallization are lost and a purple microcrystalline powder was obtained. Structure analysis of the high-resolution powder X-ray diffractogram () revealed that compound 2 had been transformed into a one-dimensional polymer {[Cu(R,Rchxn)2][Ni(CN)4]}∞ (3) (Figure a).

elements.content: (a) PXRD diffractograms illustrating the transformation of compound 2 to compound 3. (b) View of the reversible transformation of compound 2 ↔ 3, as the result of a dehydration−rehydration process (Cu - orange, Ni - green).
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) PXRD diffractograms illustrating the transformation of compound 2 to compound 3. (b) View of the reversible transformation of compound 2 ↔ 3, as the result of a dehydration-rehydration process (Cu - orange, Ni - green).

elements.content: In the crystal structure of 2 the bimetallic complexes are arranged head-to-tail in a zigzag fashion, separated by the water molecules of crystallization, and with the shortest nonbonded electrostatic Cu···NC interaction being Cu1···N1 of 3.153(3) Å (Figures b and a). On dehydration to form compound 3 the binuclear molecules of 2 aligned themselves and the copper atoms in 3 are now bridged by cyano groups, with Cu···NC bond distances of 2.146(12) and 2.722(11) Å (Figure b and , and Table ).
elements.clean_text: In the crystal structure of 2 the bimetallic complexes are arranged head-to-tail in a zigzag fashion, separated by the water molecules of crystallization, and with the shortest nonbonded electrostatic Cu⋅⋅⋅NC interaction being Cu1⋅⋅⋅N1 of 3.153(3) Å (Figures b and a). On dehydration to form compound 3 the binuclear molecules of 2 aligned themselves and the copper atoms in 3 are now bridged by cyano groups, with Cu⋅⋅⋅NC bond distances of 2.146(12) and 2.722(11) Å (Figure b and , and Table ).

Immersion of powder 3 into water revealed that the system is reversible; the original structure 2 was recovered, as shown by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure a−c). The color of the sample also changed reverting from purple to violet. Immersion of powder 3 into methanol, acetonitrile or ethyleneglycol gave violet-like microcrystalline solids with different powder X-ray diffractograms (Figure d−f). In all cases the reactions were found to be reversible. Simple heating of these new species released the solvent molecules and the final diffractograms were found to be identical to that of compound 3. Work is currently in progress to resolve the structures of these new species from their powder X-ray diffractograms.
elements.clean_text: Immersion of powder 3 into water revealed that the system is reversible; the original structure 2 was recovered, as shown by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure a-c). The color of the sample also changed reverting from purple to violet. Immersion of powder 3 into methanol, acetonitrile or ethyleneglycol gave violet-like microcrystalline solids with different powder X-ray diffractograms (Figure d-f). In all cases the reactions were found to be reversible. Simple heating of these new species released the solvent molecules and the final diffractograms were found to be identical to that of compound 3. Work is currently in progress to resolve the structures of these new species from their powder X-ray diffractograms.

elements.content: Using trans-cyclohexane-(1S,2S)-diamine instead of trans-cyclohexane-(1R,2R)-diamine we expected to obtain the enantiomer of the ionic complex 2. However, the crystal structure analysis of compound 4 revealed that it is a new one-dimensional chiral polymer {[Cu(S,S-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]·2H2O}∞ [see Figure c]. Complex 4 crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21, compared to the orthorhombic space group P212121 for compound 3; hence, it is a pseudo polymorph of 3. In 4 the Cu1 atoms of the cationic units have elongated octahedral geometry due to Jahn−Teller effects. Bond distances and angles involving the CN groups for compounds 2, 3 and 4 as compared in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[Cu(S,S-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]⋅2H2O}∞ (4)

Using trans-cyclohexane-(1S,2S)-diamine instead of trans-cyclohexane-(1R,2R)-diamine we expected to obtain the enantiomer of the ionic complex 2. However, the crystal structure analysis of compound 4 revealed that it is a new one-dimensional chiral polymer {[Cu(S,S-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]⋅2H2O}∞ [see Figure c]. Complex 4 crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21, compared to the orthorhombic space group P212121 for compound 3; hence, it is a pseudo polymorph of 3. In 4 the Cu1 atoms of the cationic units have elongated octahedral geometry due to Jahn-Teller effects. Bond distances and angles involving the CN groups for compounds 2, 3 and 4 as compared in Table .

elements.content: View of the crystal packing down the a-axis for (a) compound 2; (b) compound 3; and (c) compound 4.
elements.clean_text: 5  View of the crystal packing down the a-axis for (a) compound 2; (b) compound 3; and (c) compound 4.

elements.content: The geometrical parameters for the [Ni(CN)4]2− anion are comparable to those in known related complexes. Like complex 3, complex 4 is a one-dimensional zigzag chain composed of alternating trans-[Cu(chxn)2]2+ cations and [Ni(CN)4]2− anions running along the crystallographic b-axis (Figure c).
elements.clean_text: The geometrical parameters for the [Ni(CN)4]2- anion are comparable to those in known related complexes. Like complex 3, complex 4 is a one-dimensional zigzag chain composed of alternating trans-[Cu(chxn)2]2+ cations and [Ni(CN)4]2- anions running along the crystallographic b-axis (Figure c).

elements.content: In the crystal structure of 4, hydrogen bonding leads to the formation of a three-dimensional network (Figure ). The nonbridging CN groups of the Ni1 tetracyanonickelate moiety form hydrogen bonds with both water molecules: [D···A] 2.930(5) Å for O1w···N1, and 2.937(5) Å for O1w···N2. One of the bridging CN groups hydrogen bonds to water O2w: O2w···N4 is 3.0084 Å. The same water molecule hydrogen bonds to a NH2-group: N8···O2w is 2.8623 Å, and to water molecule O1w: O2w···O1w is 2.716(3) Å.
elements.clean_text: In the crystal structure of 4, hydrogen bonding leads to the formation of a three-dimensional network (Figure ). The nonbridging CN groups of the Ni1 tetracyanonickelate moiety form hydrogen bonds with both water molecules: [D⋅⋅⋅A] 2.930(5) Å for O1w⋅⋅⋅N1, and 2.937(5) Å for O1w⋅⋅⋅N2. One of the bridging CN groups hydrogen bonds to water O2w: O2w⋅⋅⋅N4 is 3.0084 Å. The same water molecule hydrogen bonds to a NH2-group: N8⋅⋅⋅O2w is 2.8623 Å, and to water molecule O1w: O2w⋅⋅⋅O1w is 2.716(3) Å.

elements.content: Crystal packing of compound 4 viewed along the a-axis, showing the hydrogen bonding network as red dashed lines (ligand H-atoms removed for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 6  Crystal packing of compound 4 viewed along the a-axis, showing the hydrogen bonding network as red dashed lines (ligand H-atoms removed for clarity).

elements.content: In the IR spectra, characteristic vibrations for ν(C≡N) were assigned. For complex 1, one strong band at 2133 cm−1 can be attributed to the C≡N stretching vibration. In the spectra of the 2, 3 and 4 there are two CN strong bands in the region 2116−2132 cm−1. The splitting of the νas(C≡N) compared with that of K2[Ni(CN)4] (2127 cm−1) indicates the presence of two different coordination modes (monodentate and bridging) of the cyanide ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic Analysis

In the IR spectra, characteristic vibrations for ν(C≡N) were assigned. For complex 1, one strong band at 2133 cm-1 can be attributed to the C≡N stretching vibration. In the spectra of the 2, 3 and 4 there are two CN strong bands in the region 2116-2132 cm-1. The splitting of the νas(C≡N) compared with that of K2[Ni(CN)4] (2127 cm-1) indicates the presence of two different coordination modes (monodentate and bridging) of the cyanide ligands.

elements.content: Circular dichroism measurements (Figure ) were used to establish the enantiomeric character of the coordination polymers (solid state, using KBr discs) and [Cu(trans-(1R,2R)-chxn)2(H2O)2](NO3)2 (in solution). The enantiopure bis-chelated precursor shows a positive Cotton effect at λ = 515 nm. Compound 2 exhibits a positive Cotton effects at the same wavelength, while compound 4 (S,S isomer) shows, as expected, a Cotton effect of the opposite sign at the same wavelength.
elements.clean_text: Circular dichroism measurements (Figure ) were used to establish the enantiomeric character of the coordination polymers (solid state, using KBr discs) and [Cu(trans-(1R,2R)-chxn)2(H2O)2](NO3)2 (in solution). The enantiopure bis-chelated precursor shows a positive Cotton effect at λ = 515 nm. Compound 2 exhibits a positive Cotton effects at the same wavelength, while compound 4 (S,S isomer) shows, as expected, a Cotton effect of the opposite sign at the same wavelength.

elements.content: CD spectra of (a) an acetonitrile−water solution of the bis-chelated precursor [Cu(trans-(1R,2R)-chxn) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ](NO 3 ) 2 ; (b) a powder sample of [Cu(1R,2Rchxn) 2 ][Ni(CN) 4 ]·2H 2 O (2) in a KBr matrix; (c) a powder sample of {[Cu(1S,2Schxn) 2 ][Ni(CN) 4 ]·2H 2 O} ∞ (4) in a KBr matrix.
elements.clean_text: 7  CD spectra of (a) an acetonitrile-water solution of the bis-chelated precursor [Cu(trans-(1R,2R)-chxn) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ](NO 3 ) 2 ; (b) a powder sample of [Cu(1R,2Rchxn) 2 ][Ni(CN) 4 ]⋅2H 2 O (2) in a KBr matrix; (c) a powder sample of {[Cu(1S,2Schxn) 2 ][Ni(CN) 4 ]⋅2H 2 O} ∞  (4) in a KBr matrix.

elements.content: Immersion calorimetric studies were carried out for compound 3 (). This technique, applied mainly to carbons and zeolites, provides an insight into the filling of nanopores. It is based on the determination of the enthalpy change occurring on immersing an outgassed nanoporous sample into a liquid. The enthalpy change is related to the chemical and structural nature of the surface, and the enthalpy of immersion, −Δi H, is equal to the integral of the net heat of adsorption. The enthalpy of immersion of 3, Δi H, for water gave an average value of −55.7 ± 3 J per gram of solid. This value is much higher that obtained on immersion into MeOH (average value of− 40.2 ± 3 J/g) or CH3CN (average value of −19.19 ± 3 J/g). It is interesting to note that for water the heat measured is not the heat of filling of nanopores but the heat of transformation of the one-dimensional chiral polymer into the original binuclear structure, 2. In the case of immersion of 3 into methanol and acetonitrile the X-ray diffractograms indicate the formation of new compounds, whose structures are unknown at present (Figure ): Hence the values obtained must also reflect structural transformations.
elements.clean_text:
Immersion Calorimetry

Immersion calorimetric studies were carried out for compound 3 (). This technique, applied mainly to carbons and zeolites, provides an insight into the filling of nanopores. It is based on the determination of the enthalpy change occurring on immersing an outgassed nanoporous sample into a liquid. The enthalpy change is related to the chemical and structural nature of the surface, and the enthalpy of immersion, -Δi H, is equal to the integral of the net heat of adsorption. The enthalpy of immersion of 3, Δi H, for water gave an average value of -55.7 ± 3 J per gram of solid. This value is much higher that obtained on immersion into MeOH (average value of- 40.2 ± 3 J/g) or CH3CN (average value of -19.19 ± 3 J/g). It is interesting to note that for water the heat measured is not the heat of filling of nanopores but the heat of transformation of the one-dimensional chiral polymer into the original binuclear structure, 2. In the case of immersion of 3 into methanol and acetonitrile the X-ray diffractograms indicate the formation of new compounds, whose structures are unknown at present (Figure ): Hence the values obtained must also reflect structural transformations.

elements.content: Four new bimetallic chiral tetracyanonickelate(II) complexes, two of which are one-dimensional polymers, have been synthesized and full characterized. The crystal structure of 1 consists of discrete [Ni(R,R-chxn)3]2+ cations and [Ni(CN)4]2− anions, while that of 2 consists of a bimetallic assembly of a [Cu(R,R-chxn)3]2+ cation and a [Ni(CN)4]2− anion. Compound 2 shows an interesting reversible phase transformation, triggered by heating to remove the water molecules of crystallization, to form a one-dimensional chiral polymer, 3. Changing trans-cyclohexane-(1R,2R)-diamine for trans-cyclohexane-(1S,2S)-diamine gave not the enantiomer of compound 2, but a new one-dimensional polymer with alternating trans-[Cu(S,S-chxn)2]2+ cations and [Ni(CN)4]2− anions. The chiral nature of complexes 2 and 4 has been confirmed by solid state CD measurements. By immersion calorimetric studies it was possible to determine the heat of transformation of the one-dimensional chiral polymer 3 into the binuclear structure 2. Immersion of 3 into methanol, acetonitrile or ethyleneglycol gave violet-like microcrystalline solids with different powder X-ray diffractograms. In all cases the reactions were found to be reversible. Work is currently in progress to resolve the structures of these new species.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Four new bimetallic chiral tetracyanonickelate(II) complexes, two of which are one-dimensional polymers, have been synthesized and full characterized. The crystal structure of 1 consists of discrete [Ni(R,R-chxn)3]2+ cations and [Ni(CN)4]2- anions, while that of 2 consists of a bimetallic assembly of a [Cu(R,R-chxn)3]2+ cation and a [Ni(CN)4]2- anion. Compound 2 shows an interesting reversible phase transformation, triggered by heating to remove the water molecules of crystallization, to form a one-dimensional chiral polymer, 3. Changing trans-cyclohexane-(1R,2R)-diamine for trans-cyclohexane-(1S,2S)-diamine gave not the enantiomer of compound 2, but a new one-dimensional polymer with alternating trans-[Cu(S,S-chxn)2]2+ cations and [Ni(CN)4]2- anions. The chiral nature of complexes 2 and 4 has been confirmed by solid state CD measurements. By immersion calorimetric studies it was possible to determine the heat of transformation of the one-dimensional chiral polymer 3 into the binuclear structure 2. Immersion of 3 into methanol, acetonitrile or ethyleneglycol gave violet-like microcrystalline solids with different powder X-ray diffractograms. In all cases the reactions were found to be reversible. Work is currently in progress to resolve the structures of these new species.

Crystallographic data for compounds 1−4 in CIF format, and additional information of the phase transformation in PDF format, are available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
Compound 1 was obtained as pink rod-like crystals by slow diffusion of an aqueous solution of [Ni(R,R-chxn)3]SO4 layered onto a H2O-EtOH (1:1) solution of K2[Ni(CN)4] after several weeks. Elemental analysis for C22H46N10Ni2O4: calc. C, 41.81; H, 7.34; N, 22.16, found C, 41.54; H, 7.92; N, 22.02%.

{[Cu(S,S-chxn)<sub>2</sub>][Ni(CN)<sub>4</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

Compound 4 was obtained as violet block-like crystals by slow diffusion of an acetonitrile solution of [Cu(trans-(S,S-chxn)2(H2O)](NO3)2 (1mmol, 10 mL) layered onto an aqueous solution of K2[Ni(CN)4]·H2O (1mmol, 10 mL). Elemental analysis for C16H32N8CuNiO2: calc. C, 39.16; H, 6.57; N, 22.83, found C, 39.32; H, 6.71; N, 22.93%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Syntheses

[Ni(R,R-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]⋅4H2O (1)

Compound 1 was obtained as pink rod-like crystals by slow diffusion of an aqueous solution of [Ni(R,R-chxn)3]SO4 layered onto a H2O-EtOH (1:1) solution of K2[Ni(CN)4] after several weeks. Elemental analysis for C22H46N10Ni2O4: calc. C, 41.81; H, 7.34; N, 22.16, found C, 41.54; H, 7.92; N, 22.02%.

{[Cu(S,S-chxn)2][Ni(CN)4]⋅2H2O}∞ (4)

Compound 4 was obtained as violet block-like crystals by slow diffusion of an acetonitrile solution of [Cu(trans-(S,S-chxn)2(H2O)](NO3)2 (1mmol, 10 mL) layered onto an aqueous solution of K2[Ni(CN)4]⋅H2O (1mmol, 10 mL). Elemental analysis for C16H32N8CuNiO2: calc. C, 39.16; H, 6.57; N, 22.83, found C, 39.32; H, 6.71; N, 22.93%.

cln_elements.content:
Compound 2 was obtained as violet plate-like crystals by layering an aqueous solution of [Cu(R,R-chxn)3]SO4 layered onto a H2O-EtOH(1:1) solution of K2[Ni(CN)4] after several weeks. The crystals have a slightly smaller unit cell than the same structure published by Akitsu et al., due to the fact the crystal was measured at −100 °C. Elemental analysis for C16H32N8CuNiO2: calc. C, 39.16; H, 6.57; N, 22.83, found C, 39.26; H, 6.48; N, 22.99%.

{[Cu(R,R-chxn)<sub>2</sub>][Ni(CN)<sub>4</sub>]}<sub>∞</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Complex 3 was obtained as a purple powder by heating compound 2 to 110 °C, using thermogravimetric analysis. Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C16H28N8CuNi: C, 42.27; H, 6.21; N, 24.64, found C, 42.26; H, 6.36; N, 24.26%.

metadata.title:
Chiral Bimetallic Assemblies and Coordination Polymers Based on Tetracyanonickelate: A Striking Reversible Structural Transformation
Coordination Polymers Based on Tetracyanonickelate
